paragraph.docTitle: Distribution and ecology of dictyostelids in Madagascar

subSection.paragraph: JAMES C. CAVENDER 1 , JOHN C. LANDOLT 2 , EDUARDO M. VADELL 3 , ALLISON L. PERRIGO 4,5 , STEVEN L. STEPHENSON 6 , DIANA WRIGLEY DE BASANTA 7 , CARLOS LADO 8 & PU LIU 9

subSection.paragraph: � puliu1982@yahoo.com; https://orcid.org/0000-0003-4079-8566

Samples for isolation of dictyostelid cellular slime molds were obtained from 20 collecting sites at 18 localities in south central and southeastern Madagascar during
May 2009
. At least thirty species of dictyostelids representing seven genera were recovered from 52 samples of soil/humus. This total included 17 species described as new to science, 13 species already known from various localities throughout the world, and four isolates that remain unidentified. Fourteen of the new species isolated from these samples are members of the whorl-branched, light-spored genus
Heterostelium
(formerly
Polysphondylium
). The overall level of species richness of dictyostelids in Madagascar is greater than what is known for all of mainland Africa sampled to date. Levels of biodiversity in Madagascar were higher for mesic than for xeric vegetation types , and each of the newly described species of
Heterostelium
appeared to have a limited distribution among the localities sampled
.

Keywords: biodiversity, ecology,
Heterostelium
, island biogeography, slime molds, species richness

The dictyostelids (Phylum Amoebozoa), also known as cellular slime molds or social amoebae, are a group of eukaryotic microorganisms commonly found in soils worldwide, where they are ecologically important as predators of soil bacteria ( Raper 1984 ). Dictyostelids are particularly well known for eastern North America, western Europe, and portions of China (
Liu et al. 2020
), where they have widely studied for several decades. Much of the remainder of the world is understudied. This is particularly true for most areas of the Southern Hemisphere, where the most noteworthy studies appear to be those carried out in New Zealand by
Cavender et al. (2002)
, Australia by
Landolt et al. (2008)
, southern South America by
Vadell et al. (2011)
, and South Africa by
Cavender et al. (2018)
. The first publication on the dictyostelids of Madagascar was by
Cavender et al. (2016)
but was limited to the description of several new species with little ecological data.

Madagascar is the world’s fourth largest oceanic island and has a total area of 59,280 km 2 . Long part of the supercontinent of Gondwana, it separated along with Africa and India from the rest of Gondwana (South America, Australia , India , and Antarctica ) about 150 to 160 million years ago and then split off from India during the period of 84 to 91 million years ago ( Wells 2003 ). Madagascar has remained geologically isolated since then (
Masters et al. 2006
,
Kusky et al. 2007
). The island has an elliptical shape and much of it consists of a large central plateau that ranges in elevation from 800–1,800 m and has a cover of vegetation that consists largely of savannah-steppe. There are some highlands in the northern part of the island, and a lowland belt that is now mostly cultivated surrounds the interior plateau. Major eco-regions found in Madagascar include tropical broadleaf forest remnants on the eastern coast and east-facing slopes of the plateau, subhumid forests in the highlands above 2,000 m and gallery forests in ravines on the plateau, a transition to ericoid thickets in the south, abundant mature grasslands and shrublands, spiny thickets in the far south, dry deciduous forests in the southwest and some areas of semi-desert ( The Nature Conservancy 2009 , Figs. 1–12 ). The true tropical rainforest remnants along the east coast have an annual monsoonal rainfall of up to 4,000 mm , but the remainder of the country is much drier. The driest and coolest season of the portion of Madagascar considered in the present study extends from May to October, with the period between September and October especially dry. The wettest and warmest season occurs during the period of November to April, with an annual rainfall of 1,400 mm at the capital of Antananarivo ( Koechlin 1972 ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–12. Madagascar vegetation at some of the collecting sites. 1. Ranomafana National Park, subhumid tropical forest. 2. Ranomafana, subhumid tropical forest. 3. Mandraka, primary montane tropical wet forest. 4. Grassland. 5. L’Isalo National Park with
Pandanus sp.
present. 6. Road to Betroka, grassland with
Eucalyptus sp.
present. 7. L’Isalo National Park, sclerophyllous forest. 8.Andringitra National Park, fallow grassland with shrubs. 9. Ambositra, sclerophyllous
Uapaca bojerii
community. 10. Succulent scrub with
Pachypodium sp.
11. Betroka-Beraketa xerophytic succulent scrub. 12. Near Berenty National Reserve, dry forest with
Alluaudia sp

subSection.paragraph:
Fifty-four samples of soil/humus were obtained from Madagascar during a three-week period in May 2009 , which coincided with the end of the rainy season. These 54 samples came from 20 collecting sites in 18 separate localities ( Fig. 13 ) representing 12 different types of natural vegetation that included examples characterized by mesic or xeric moisture regimes ( Table 1 ). All samples were sent to two different coauthor laboratories for processing, with each laboratory receiving 27 replicate samples (half of the total 54). Isolation procedures for dictyostelids followed Cavender and Raper (1965) , with additional information relating to the culture techniques used described in
Cavender et al. (2016)
. Later, all isolates were further reviewed by additional coauthors for morphological characterization.

caption.paragraph: FIGURE 13. Map of collecting sites in Madagascar (see Table 2).

subSection.paragraph:
Although 54 samples were collected and sent to the two laboratories, two of these samples were excluded from processing because they were very dry and consisted mostly of pebbles. Although 18 different localities were sampled, two of these (MGR-09-14 and MGR-09-29) encompassed examples of both a xeric site and a mesic site. As such, there were a total of 20 collecting sites in the 18 localities. The assemblage of species of dictyostelids now known from Madagascar was compared with those reported for mainland Africa, Australia , China , Costa Rica , Mexico , Tikal (in Guatemala ), and the United States ( Vadell and Cavender 1995 ,
Landolt et al. 2008
, Cavender et al. 2010,
Landolt et al. 2014
,
Liu et al. 2020
), where comparable sets of data are available (Table 3). For the purpose of this comparison, only isolates reliably referred to a particular species were considered, and all sub-specific identifications (e.g., varieties and subspecies) were excluded. For each region, data are provided for the total number of species, the number of species shared in common with Madagascar , the coefficient of community index for the pairwise combination of Madagascar and the region in question, and the percentage of the total number of species represented by members of the genus
Heterostelium
. The coefficient of community index used herein was CC = 2c/(a = b), where a = the total number of species in the first set of data being compared, b = the number of species in the second set of data being compared, and c = the number of species shared in common between the two sets of data ( Gauch 1982 ). Coefficient of community values range from 0 to 1.0, where 0 indicates no common species shared between two study areas or datasets and 1 indicates that all species are common to both study areas or sets of data.

Nomenclature used herein follows Sheikh et al. (2017) except for the five newly described species reported by
Perrigo et al. (2020)
.

caption.paragraph: TABLE 1. Summary data on the collecting sites in Madagascar where samples for isolation of dictyostelids were obtained.
The numbers in brackets refer to the collecting site designations used in Table 2. Vegetation types essentially follow those

subSection.paragraph: outlined by The Nature Conservancy (2009) .

subSection.paragraph:
The 52 samples of soil/humus processed for dictyostelids yielded 34 species in seven genera. This total included 17 species described as new to science, 13 species already known from various localities throughout the world, and four isolates that remain unidentified to the level of species. Fourteen of the new species are members of the whorlbranched, light-spored genus
Heterostelium
(formerly
Polysphondylium
) (
Cavender et al. 2016
). The 52 samples also yielded two new species in the genus
Cavenderia
and one in the genus
Raperostelium
. There is one additional new species (
H. migatissimum
) now known for Madagascar that was isolated from samples collected from a karst cave in the northern portion of the island in a separate study. This species is not included in Table 2 because it was considered outside the scope of the research being reported in the present paper..

Altogether there were 12 xeric forest, shrub, and grassland collecting sites in eleven different localities. Samples from three of these localities did not yield any clones of dictyostelids at the time sampling was carried out. Three collecting sites in the same number of localities considered as mesic yielded only a single clone. The seven mesic localities included subhumid tropical, primary montane tropical and gallery forests bordering streams, and higher elevation grasslands. All samples except two obtained from subhumid tropical forest collecting sites had dictyostelids. These data suggest that populations of dictyostelids at a particular collecting site tend to reflect environmental conditions, with both overall abundance and species richness higher for vegetation types associated with mesic collecting sites as opposed to those associated with xeric collecting sites ( Fig. 14 ).

Xeric sites had more clones of the larger species of dictyostelids (e.g.,
Dictyostelium purpureum , D. giganteum ,
and
Polysphondylium violaceum
) as well as the new species of
Heterostelium
. In contrast, mesic sites had more of the smaller species of dictyostelids (e.g.,
Cavenderia deminutivum , Hagiwaraea lavandulum , D. implicatum
, and
Coremiostelium polycephalum
) as well as the two newly described yellow-pigmented species
Cavenderia canoesporum
and
C . basinodulosum (
Perrigo et al. 2020
)
. The predominantly grassy habitats yielded just two species (
Dictyostelium giganteum
and
D. leptosomum
).

Dictyostelium purpureum
was the most widespread species and was recorded at seven collecting sites and in six different types of habitats.
Dictyostelium giganteum
was the only other species recorded from at least five collecting sites ( Fig. 15 ). The 14 new species of
Heterostelium
were found at 10 collecting sites and in seven different habitats, with nine from mesic collecting sites and six from xeric collecting sites. A single species was recorded from both mesic and xeric collecting sites.

caption.paragraph: FIGURE 14. Total number of clones and number of clones per sample for collecting sites in Madagascar.

FIGURE 15. Distribution of
Dictyostelium purpureum
and
D . giganteum
in the major forest types in Madagascar.

subSection.paragraph:
Some of the species in the assemblage present in Madagascar appear are similar to those reported for the assemblages known from tropical forests in Mexico and Tikal, Guatemala . For example,
Cavenderia deminutivum
was first isolated from a seasonal rain forest near Veracruz , Mexico ( Cavender and Raper 1968 ) and has been reported several times since then, but only in Central America. This species occurred quite abundantly in the Ranomafana subhumid forest in Madagascar but has not yet been reported from elsewhere in Africa, although this does not preclude it being present. Also recorded were two species of yellow-pigmented dictyostelids reminiscent of the yellow-pigmented species
C. granulophorum
and
C. medusoides
from Tikal, Guatemala (
Vadell et al. 1995
).Another similarity with Central America was the presence in Madagascar of a species very similar to
Heterostelium colligatum
, a species first described from Tikal ( Vadell and Cavender 1998 ).

Madagascar is characterized by one of the highest number of species (14) of
Heterostelium
of any region of the world sampled to date. This could well represent an example of radiation after several colonization events by one or two species. As
Madagascar separated and drifted northward into a region of the world characterized by a more tropical climate, new environments related to different types of vegetation were created that were subsequently colonized by
Heterostelium
and the genus might have been selected for new morphologies under the new conditions. However, it should be noted that over recent geological time, the climate of
Madagascar ( Wells 2003 ), like the rest of the world, has undergone change. For example, Li et al. (2000) indicated that there is evidence to suggest that Madagascar has been subjected to catastrophic ecological and landscape transformation due to such factors as human activities and island-wide drought during the past 8,000 years. It is not known what impact this might have had on dictyostelids.

As indicated by the figures provided in Table 3, total numbers of species of dictyostelids reported to date ranged from 22 ( Australia ) to 46 ( United States ) and China (54). It seems likely that the highest numbers are related to differences in the sizes of the regions surveyed. For example, China is sixteen times the size of Madagascar . However, the total for Madagascar is higher than those of five other regions despite the fact that most of the data for the island were obtained from a single collecting trip. The number of species shared in common with Madagascar ranged from six to 11 with one noteworthy exception—Tikal. These totals are reflected in the coefficient of community values, which were fairly consistent (range 0.21 to 0.29), except for Tikal, which had a much lower value (0.07). Clearly, the assemblages of dictyostelids for Madagascar and Tikal vary rather considerably at the level of species.

The large number of species of
Heterostelium
recorded from Madagascar was noted earlier in this paper. Representatives of this genus made up almost half (48%) of all species recorded. Australia had the next highest total (32%). This could be linked to the fact that both Madagascar and Australia are isolated land masses characterized by a predominantly xeric climate. However, Tikal, with the next highest percentage of species of
Heterostelium
, has a mesic and not a xeric climate.

Although the present study was limited in extent, examining the data from just 52 samples from 20 different collecting sites in the central and southern part of the island, the results indicate that Madagascar has a species rich and distinct assemblage of dictyostelids, a pattern that is likewise observed in many other larger taxa such as plants and animals. Mainland Africa as a whole, based on the sampling carried out to date, appears to have one of the least biodiverse assemblages of dictyostelids of any continent, with the subcontinent of India also appearing to be characterized by a low level of biodiversity ( Cavender and Lakhanpal 1986 ). In contrast, Madagascar may have one of the most species rich assemblages of any region of comparable size anywhere in the world, based on the data currently available. There are some interesting correspondences between the dictyostelids of Central America and Madagascar that have not shown up in comparison with the rest of Africa. It is not immediately apparent why this occurs, even considering the breakup of Gondwana. However, the range of habitats available (at least those from which samples have been collected) may represent a factor. Of particular interest is the apparent speciation in the genus
Heterostelium
, which was found to occur prolifically in Madagascar .

Table 3. Summary data on the assemblages of dictyostelids reported from several different regions of the world. Note: MAD = Madagascar , MEX = Mexico , AUS = Australia , CHI = China and USA = United States , AFR = Africa, CR = Costa Rica and TRK = Tikal.

paragraph.tableNote: 1 Coefficient of community values for pairwise combinations with MAD

subSection.paragraph: The expedition to Madagascar was funded by a grant (DEB-0316284) from the National Science Foundation to the University of Arkansas. Appreciation is extended to Carlos Rojas for preparing the images used for Figures 14 and 15 . We thank National Parks of Madagascar for giving us permission to collect in the various localities.
